base_note.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Charles Davis
MRN: 8684379
DOB: 06/20/1958 (66 years old)
Date of Procedure: 2025-03-07
Location: Stanford Medical Center, Palo Alto, CA

Attending: Dr. Priya Patel, MD
Fellow: Dr. Kevin Nguyen, MD (PGY-6)
RN: Anna Martinez
RT: Brian Lee

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Persistent bronchopleural fistula (BPF) with prolonged air leak, post right upper lobectomy for lung cancer (POD #14)

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial valve placement for bronchopleural fistula/air leak closure

INDICATION: 66-year-old male status post right upper lobectomy for stage IIA squamous cell carcinoma 14 days ago, complicated by persistent air leak via chest tube (continuous, >500mL/breath). CT chest shows persistent right apical pneumothorax with bronchial stump intact but suspected peripheral alveolar-pleural fistula in the remaining RML/RLL. Given poor surgical candidacy for re-thoracotomy (COPD, recent surgery, poor nutritional status), endobronchial valve placement was planned for non-surgical management of the air leak.

NOTE: This is NOT a BLVR procedure for emphysema/lung volume reduction. The indication is therapeutic air leak closure in the setting of BPF.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia (TIVA) with single-lumen ETT

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:
Patient intubated and positioned supine. Flexible bronchoscopy performed. Airway inspection revealed:
- Trachea: Normal
- Right bronchial stump: Healing well, no gross leak
- Right bronchus intermedius: Patent
- Right middle lobe: Patent, normal appearance
- Right lower lobe: Segmental bronchi appeared inflamed but patent
- Left lung: Normal

Balloon occlusion testing was performed to identify the leaking segment. Sequential balloon occlusion of right lower lobe segments revealed:
- RB6 (superior segment): Partial reduction in air leak
- RB7-10 (basal segments): Further reduction with RB9 occlusion
- Combined RB6 + RB9 occlusion: Complete cessation of air leak

Based on balloon occlusion testing, decision was made to place endobronchial valves in RB6 and RB9.

Valve placement:
1. RB6 (superior segment): Zephyr 4.0mm EBV deployed. Good fit, no air flow around valve.
2. RB9 (lateral basal segment): Zephyr 4.0-LP EBV deployed. Good fit.

Post-valve bronchoscopy confirmed valves in good position. Patient's chest tube placed to water seal at end of procedure.

Immediate post-procedure assessment showed COMPLETE CESSATION of air leak on the chest tube drainage system.

DEVICES:
- Zephyr EBV 4.0mm x 1 (RB6)
- Zephyr EBV 4.0-LP x 1 (RB9)

SPECIMENS: None

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: Minimal

DISPOSITION: Return to thoracic surgery floor. Chest tube to water seal. If no air leak for 48 hours, will remove chest tube.

FOLLOW-UP: Will monitor for valve expectoration. Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks for potential valve removal if air leak remains resolved. Valves may be permanent if necessary.

Dr. Priya Patel, MD
Dr. Kevin Nguyen, MD

registry_entry.primary_indication: Bronchopleural fistula with persistent air leak - post lobectomy

evidence.primary_indication: Persistent BPF/air leak POD#14 post RUL lobectomy

registry_entry.institution_name: Stanford Medical Center, Palo Alto, CA

blvr_valve_placements.notes: First valve for BPF closure
Second valve - complete air leak cessation achieved

code_rationales.31647: Bronchoscopy with placement of bronchial valve(s), initial lobe. Same CPT codes (31647/31651) are used for valve placement regardless of indication (BPF vs emphysema/BLVR).
code_rationales.31651: Add-on for additional valve in same lobe (second valve in RLL).

coding_review.overall_assessment: BPF/AIR LEAK VALVE CASE: Endobronchial valves placed for bronchopleural fistula air leak management, NOT for lung volume reduction/emphysema. Same CPT codes apply but registry/tagging should distinguish this from true BLVR cases. Label should be 'blvr' but with indication noted as 'Fistula/Air Leak'.

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with endobronchial valve placement, initial bronchus
Bronchoscopy; with endobronchial valve placement, each additional bronchus (add-on)

changes: Populated registry_entry.billing from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 for CPT codes 31647, +31651; total_work_rvu=10.0, total_rvu=15.83 (facility).

variations.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE DOCUMENTATION
============================================================

PATIENT IDENTIFICATION AND DEMOGRAPHICS
----------------------------------------
Patient: Kevin Fisher
Medical Record Number: 4873766
Date of Birth: 06/20/1954
Age at Procedure: 70 years
Procedure Date: 2024-12-07

CLINICAL INDICATION AND PREOPERATIVE ASSESSMENT
----------------------------------------
The patient presented with bronchopleural fistula with persistent air leak - post lobectomy. Following comprehensive multidisciplinary evaluation and informed consent discussion detailing procedural risks, benefits, and alternatives, the patient elected to proceed with the proposed intervention.

PROCEDURAL METHODOLOGY AND TECHNIQUE
----------------------------------------

Blvr:
Endobronchial valve deployment was performed following comprehensive collateral ventilation assessment to ensure treatment candidacy. 

INTRAPROCEDURAL FINDINGS
----------------------------------------
Detailed airway examination was performed with findings as documented in the procedural narrative.


POSTPROCEDURAL ASSESSMENT AND DISPOSITION
----------------------------------------
The procedure was completed without immediate complications. The patient demonstrated hemodynamic stability throughout and was transferred to the recovery area in satisfactory condition.

PROCEDURAL CODING DOCUMENTATION
----------------------------------------
Current Procedural Terminology Codes: 31647, 31651

This documentation has been prepared in accordance with institutional standards for procedural documentation and coding compliance.

PROCEDURE NOTE - CODING DOCUMENTATION
============================================================

Patient: Adam Jackson | MRN: 5681034 | DOS: 2025-06-04

CPT CODE JUSTIFICATION
----------------------------------------

CPT 31647:
  Rationale: Bronchoscopy with placement of bronchial valve(s), initial lobe. Same CPT codes (31647/31651) are used for valve placement regardless of indication (BPF vs emphysema/BLVR).
  Facility RVU: 11.15
  Facility Payment: $361

CPT 31651:
  Rationale: Add-on for additional valve in same lobe (second valve in RLL).
  Facility RVU: 4.28
  Facility Payment: $138

DOCUMENTED TECHNIQUES AND EQUIPMENT
----------------------------------------

  • Zephyr 4
  • Zephyr EBV

PROCEDURE-SPECIFIC DOCUMENTATION:

BLVR:
  - Indication: Bronchopleural fistula/air leak
  - Indication Not Emphysema: True
  - Valve Type: Zephyr (Pulmonx)
  - Number Of Valves: 2
  - Target Lobes: ['RLL']
  - Chartis Performed: False
  - Balloon Occlusion Testing: True

TOTAL RVU SUMMARY:
----------------------------------------
  Total Facility RVU: 15.43
  Total Facility Payment: $499.0

Documentation supports medical necessity and procedure complexity as coded.

variations.note_text:
On 2024-07-18, Miguel Wong, a 62-year-old male (MRN 8337766), underwent bronchoscopic evaluation for Bronchopleural fistula with persistent air leak - post lobectomy. The patient received General and the procedure was performed in standard fashion. The procedure included blvr. 

On examination, the airways were systematically inspected. The visualized airways appeared patent without significant abnormality. The procedure was completed without immediate complications. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Specimens obtained were sent for appropriate analysis and results will be reviewed at follow-up. The preliminary assessment is bpf/air leak - post-surgical. 

Procedural coding: 31647, 31651.

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Bryan Roberts
MRN: 4555344
DOB: 06/20/1959 (66 years old)
Date of Procedure: 2025-08-27
Location: Stanford Medical Center, Palo Alto, CA

Attending: Dr. Priya Patel, MD
Fellow: Dr. Kevin Nguyen, MD (PGY-6)
RN: Anna Martinez
RT: Brian Lee

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Persistent bronchopleural fistula (BPF) with prolonged air leak, post right upper lobectomy for lung cancer (POD #14)

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial valve placement for bronchopleural fistula/air leak closure

INDICATION: 66-year-old male status post right upper lobectomy for stage IIA squamous cell carcinoma 14 days ago, complicated by persistent air leak via chest tube (continuous, >500mL/breath). CT chest shows persistent right apical pneumothorax with bronchial stump intact but suspected peripheral alveolar-pleural fistula in the remaining RML/RLL. Given poor surgical candidacy for re-thoracotomy (COPD, recent surgery, poor nutritional status), endobronchial valve placement was planned for non-surgical management of the air leak.

NOTE: This is NOT a BLVR procedure for emphysema/lung volume reduction. The indication is therapeutic air leak closure in the setting of BPF.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia (TIVA) with single-lumen ETT

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:
Patient intubated and positioned supine. Flexible bronchoscopy completed. Airway inspection exhibited:
- Trachea: Normal
- Right bronchial stump: Healing well, no gross leak
- Right bronchus intermedius: Open
- Right middle lobe: Open, normal appearance
- Right lower lobe: Segmental bronchi appeared inflamed but open
- Left lung: Normal

Balloon occlusion testing was completed to identify the leaking segment. Sequential balloon occlusion of right lower lobe segments exhibited:
- RB6 (superior segment): Partial reduction in air leak
- RB7-10 (basal segments): Further reduction with RB9 occlusion
- Combined RB6 + RB9 occlusion: Complete cessation of air leak

Based on balloon occlusion testing, decision was made to place endobronchial valves in RB6 and RB9.

Valve placement:
1. RB6 (superior segment): Zephyr 4.0mm EBV placed. Good fit, no air flow around valve.
2. RB9 (lateral basal segment): Zephyr 4.0-LP EBV placed. Good fit.

Post-valve bronchoscopy established valves in good position. Patient's chest tube introduced to water seal at end of procedure.

Immediate post-procedure assessment exhibited COMPLETE CESSATION of air leak on the chest tube drainage system.

DEVICES:
- Zephyr EBV 4.0mm x 1 (RB6)
- Zephyr EBV 4.0-LP x 1 (RB9)

SPECIMENS: None

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: Minimal

DISPOSITION: Return to thoracic surgery floor. Chest tube to water seal. If no air leak for 48 hours, will remove chest tube.

FOLLOW-UP: Will monitor for valve expectoration. Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks for potential valve removal if air leak remains resolved. Valves may be permanent if necessary.

Dr. Priya Patel, MD
Dr. Kevin Nguyen, MD
